secondaryConditions.name: Sleep Apnea
secondaryConditions.explanation: PTSD commonly causes sleep disturbances, nightmares, and hypervigilance, which can lead to or aggravate sleep apnea. Many veterans with PTSD develop sleep apnea as a secondary condition.
evidenceTypes: Lay statement about nightmares and sleep disruption
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Multiple studies show correlation between PTSD and sleep apnea, including increased risk of obstructive sleep apnea in veterans with PTSD.

secondaryConditions.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
secondaryConditions.explanation: PTSD and chronic stress can affect the gut-brain connection, leading to IBS symptoms including diarrhea, constipation, and abdominal pain.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Research demonstrates strong connection between PTSD/anxiety and IBS through gut-brain axis dysfunction.

secondaryConditions.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
secondaryConditions.explanation: PTSD medications (SSRIs) and chronic stress can cause or worsen GERD. Many veterans report GERD symptoms starting after PTSD diagnosis or treatment.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Studies show increased prevalence of GERD in PTSD patients, partially due to medication side effects.

secondaryConditions.name: Migraine Headaches
secondaryConditions.explanation: PTSD-related stress, tension, and hypervigilance can trigger chronic migraines. Sleep disturbances from PTSD also contribute to headache frequency.
evidenceTypes: Evidence of PTSD triggers causing headaches
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Migraine prevalence is significantly higher in PTSD patients compared to general population.

secondaryConditions.name: Major Depressive Disorder
secondaryConditions.explanation: PTSD and depression often co-occur. Chronic PTSD symptoms can lead to development of clinical depression over time.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: High comorbidity rates between PTSD and major depression well-documented in veteran populations.

secondaryConditions.name: Sciatica (Sciatic Nerve)
secondaryConditions.explanation: Herniated or bulging discs in the lower back commonly compress the sciatic nerve, causing radiating pain down the leg, numbness, and weakness.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Sciatica is a direct complication of disc herniation in 90% of cases.

secondaryConditions.name: Knee Limitation
secondaryConditions.explanation: Chronic back pain causes altered gait and compensatory movement patterns, leading to increased stress on the knees and eventual knee degeneration.
evidenceTypes: Timeline showing back pain preceded knee pain
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Biomechanical studies show altered gait from back pain increases knee joint loading by 20-40%.

secondaryConditions.name: Hip Limitation
secondaryConditions.explanation: Back pain compensation causes hip overuse and degeneration. Veterans with back injuries often develop hip arthritis from altered movement patterns.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Hip and back pain frequently co-occur due to shared biomechanical stressors.

secondaryConditions.name: Sciatica
secondaryConditions.explanation: Lower back strain and muscle spasms can compress the sciatic nerve, causing radiating leg pain.
evidenceTypes: Physical exam showing positive straight leg raise
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Lumbar strain commonly causes sciatic nerve irritation.

secondaryConditions.name: Knee Limitation
secondaryConditions.explanation: Compensatory gait from back pain leads to knee stress and degeneration over time.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Altered gait mechanics increase knee joint stress.

secondaryConditions.name: Back (IVDS)
secondaryConditions.explanation: Knee pain causes compensatory posture and gait changes, increasing stress on the lower back and causing disc degeneration.
evidenceTypes: Timeline showing knee pain preceded back pain
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Knee pathology alters spinal loading patterns.

secondaryConditions.name: Ankle/Foot Issues
secondaryConditions.explanation: Knee instability causes altered ankle mechanics and increased foot/ankle stress.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Kinetic chain dysfunction links knee and ankle pathology.

secondaryConditions.name: PTSD
secondaryConditions.explanation: TBI and PTSD often co-occur from blast exposure or combat trauma. TBI can increase vulnerability to PTSD development.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: High comorbidity rates in blast-exposed veterans.

secondaryConditions.name: Migraine Headaches
secondaryConditions.explanation: Post-concussion syndrome commonly includes chronic migraines as a persistent symptom of TBI.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Migraines are one of the most common post-TBI symptoms.

secondaryConditions.name: Tinnitus
secondaryConditions.explanation: Blast-related TBI often damages auditory pathways, causing chronic tinnitus.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Blast TBI frequently damages auditory processing.

secondaryConditions.name: Sleep Apnea
secondaryConditions.explanation: Chronic nasal congestion and obstruction from rhinitis can lead to or worsen sleep apnea.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Nasal obstruction is a known risk factor for obstructive sleep apnea.

secondaryConditions.name: Chronic Sinusitis
secondaryConditions.explanation: Chronic rhinitis inflammation can progress to recurrent or chronic sinusitis.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Rhinitis frequently progresses to chronic sinusitis.

secondaryConditions.name: Sleep Apnea
secondaryConditions.explanation: Sinus inflammation and nasal obstruction can contribute to sleep-disordered breathing.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Chronic sinusitis is associated with increased sleep apnea risk.

secondaryConditions.name: Migraine Headaches
secondaryConditions.explanation: Chronic sinus pressure and inflammation can trigger or worsen migraines.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Sinus headaches can trigger migraine episodes.

secondaryConditions.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
secondaryConditions.explanation: Diabetes commonly causes nerve damage (diabetic neuropathy) in the feet and legs, leading to numbness, tingling, and pain.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Diabetic neuropathy affects up to 50% of diabetes patients.

secondaryConditions.name: Diabetic Retinopathy
secondaryConditions.explanation: Diabetes damages blood vessels in the retina, causing vision problems and potential blindness.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Diabetic retinopathy is a leading cause of blindness in diabetics.

secondaryConditions.name: Hypertension
secondaryConditions.explanation: Diabetes and hypertension often co-occur and share metabolic risk factors.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Diabetes significantly increases hypertension risk.

secondaryConditions.name: Kidney Disease
secondaryConditions.explanation: Chronic hypertension damages kidney blood vessels, leading to chronic kidney disease.
evidenceTypes: Lab work showing declining kidney function
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Hypertension is the second leading cause of kidney disease.

secondaryConditions.name: Tinnitus
secondaryConditions.explanation: Hearing loss and tinnitus often occur together from noise exposure or auditory damage.
secondaryConditions.medicalLiterature: Tinnitus accompanies hearing loss in majority of cases.
